cHJvamVjdC10aXRsZV9BbmFseXNpbmcgYW5kIGFz.text: Analysing and assessing crop suitability for Oxfam

cHJvamVjdC1jb250ZW50c19XZSBoYXZlIGRldmVs.text:
We have developed a crop suitability tool for Oxfam. At this stage, the tool produces maps showing the number of feasible crop cycles for maize, sorghum and pearl millet in the Sahel, Sub-Saharan Africa and Dry Corridor for the selected clime periods and emission scenarios.

Climate change is expected to disproportionately affect smallholder farmers, who already face numerous risks to agricultural production. Crops will respond to specific changes in temperature and precipitation at the locations where they are currently grown.

cGFnZS1jb250ZW50c19JZGVudGlmeSB0aGUgaW5k.text:
Identify the indicators of environmental impact that are appropriate for your case and carry out the necessary studies, both at the level of monitoring and forecasting and planning, based on the use of satellite Earth Observation information, largely based on highly specific raw data, public and free acquired by European satellites under the Copernicus program.

Lobelia is a spin-off of isardSAT, a lead company providing services and solutions in the Earth Observation field.

cGFnZS10aXRsZV9Ib3cgY2FuIHdlIGhlbHAgeW91.text: How can we help you cope with this climate?

cHJvamVjdC1jb250ZW50c19XZSBoYXZlIGRldmVs.text:
We have developed a crop suitability tool for Oxfam. At this stage, the tool produces maps showing the number of feasible crop cycles for maize, sorghum and pearl millet in the Sahel, Sub-Saharan Africa and Dry Corridor for the selected clime periods and emission scenarios.

Climate change is expected to disproportionately affect smallholder farmers, who already face numerous risks to agricultural production. Crops will respond to specific changes in temperature and precipitation at the locations where they are currently grown.

## Sahel

Maize / sorghum / pearl millet

## Sub-Saharan Africa

Maize / sorghum / pearl millet / rice / cassava / beans / groundnuts / yam

## Dry Corridor

Maize / sorghum / beans / rice

cHJvamVjdC10aXRsZV9XaGF0IHdpbGwgYmUgdGhl.text: What will be the most suitable crops in Africa and Central America?

cHJvamVjdC1zaG9ydFRpdGxlX1doYXQgd2lsbCBi.text: What will be the most suitable crops in Africa and Central America?

cHJvamVjdC1jb250ZW50c19DbGltYXRlIGNoYW5n.text:
Climate change is expected to disproportionately affect smallholder farmers, who already face numerous risks to their agricultural production. Crop varieties will respond differently to changes in temperature and precipitation at the locations where they are currently grown. A **crop suitability index** is an important component of assessment studies, including changes to crop geographic distribution under climate change in the coming decades.

Lobelia has developed a crop suitability tool for Oxfam. The growth simulator produces maps showing the number of feasible cycles for staple crops in the Sahel, Sub-Saharan Africa and Dry Corridor for the selected climate periods and emission scenarios.

## Sahel

Maize / sorghum / pearl millet

## Sub-Saharan Africa

Maize / sorghum / pearl millet / rice / cassava / beans / groundnuts / yam

## Dry Corridor

Maize / sorghum / beans / rice

cHJvamVjdC10aXRsZV9TdXBwb3J0aW5nIFVOwqBI.text: Supporting UN Habitat for climate analysis in cities

cHJvamVjdC1zaG9ydFRpdGxlX1N1cHBvcnRpbmcg.text: Supporting UN Habitat for climate analysis in cities

cHJvamVjdC1jb250ZW50c19DaXRpZXMgYW5kIHVy.text:
Cities and urban areas are strongly influenced by climate change. The impacts of these changes are studied and followed by local authorities with the aim to adapt their infrastructure and minimise the effects on their quality of life, health care, transport, water management, energy supply, etc. 

The most vulnerable regions are poorly-designed urban areas lacking soil sealing, green areas, impermeability and drainage structures.

Lobelia supports climate adaptability assessments by studying the local effects of climate change in specific urban areas such as Asunción, Yakutsk, Maputo, Dakar and Port Vila.

To do so, we **downscale and bias-correct climate change projections** for these areas. This is to obtain high-resolution maps of the future climate, especially adapted to the area. The statistics and indexes we derive are extremely useful indicators that will allow a better understanding of the climate evolution for the targeted cities. 

## Example indicators

Number of tropical or frost nights, heat waves or cold waves and their duration, wet and dry consecutive days, etc.


cHJvamVjdC10aXRsZV9BZnJpY2FuIGF1dGhvcml0.text: African authorities use satellite data to prevent floods in West Africa

cHJvamVjdC1zaG9ydFRpdGxlX0FmcmljYW4gYXV0.text: African authorities use satellite data to prevent floods in West Africa

cHJvamVjdC1jb250ZW50c19GbG9vZHMgYXJlIGEg.text:
Floods are a rapidly growing concern in West Africa, projected to increase with climate change. There is a great need for reliable access to **operational flood forecasts and alerts** produced by a robust information and communication technology system adapted to regional conditions and operated by capable West African institutions.

Lobelia and isardSAT are providing **satellite-based water level observations** of the Niger River basin floodplain that are sequentially assimilated into a hydrodynamic model produced by the Swedish Meteorological and Hydrological Institute (SMHI) to generate river discharge return periods. These are used in SMHI’s flood forecasting and early-warning alert system in West Africa through the cloud-based [Hydrology Thematic Exploitation Platform (H-TEP)](https://hydrology-tep.eo.esa.int) managed by isardSAT.

Our satellite-based data on surface water extent and levels have been considered to  complement in-situ measurements. They can also be used as a proxy of streamflow, for model calibration and validation as well as for hydrologic data assimilation.

cHJvamVjdC10aXRsZV9QcmVkaWN0aW5nIHBsYWd1.text: Predicting plague outbreaks two months in advance

cHJvamVjdC1zaG9ydFRpdGxlX1ByZWRpY3Rpbmcg.text: Predicting plague outbreaks two months in advance

cHJvamVjdC1jb250ZW50c19TYXRlbGxpdGUgaW5m.text:
Satellite information is being used in a new way to predict favourable conditions for **desert locust swarms**. The new technology helps to increase the warning time for locust outbreaks by up to two months.

Using data from satellites such as soil moisture (SMELLS mission) and ocean salinity (SMOS mission), a new tool has been developed to monitor the conditions that can lead to swarming locusts, such as high moisture and green vegetation. Swarming occurs when a period of drought is followed by abundant rains and rapid vegetation growth.

**Lobelia operates the soil moisture service produced by isardSAT.**

## Where?

FAO has validated the tool in Algeria, Mali, Mauritania and Morocco.

*During the latest outbreak in Mauritania (2016)*, the team was able to identify a time lag of about 70 days from the initial signs of soil moisture to when the outbreak eventually occurred.

## Why?

A swarm measuring one square kilometre contains about 40 million locusts, which eat the same amount of food in one day as about 35,000 people.

More than 8 million people in West Africa were affected during the 2003-2005 plague, in which cereal crops were wiped out and up to 90% of legumes and pasture were destroyed. It took nearly $600 million and 13 million litres of pesticide to bring it under control.

cHJvamVjdC10aXRsZV9IZWxwaW5nIGNpdGllcyB0.text: Helping cities to turn green with air quality knowledge from satellites

cHJvamVjdC1zaG9ydFRpdGxlX0hlbHBpbmcgY2l0.text: Helping cities to turn green with air quality knowledge from satellites

cHJvamVjdC1jb250ZW50c18jIyBFbWlzc2lvbnMK.text:
## Emissions

Monthly regional emissions from satellites at 1-km resolution.

## Forecast

Hourly air quality forecasts for 3 days in advance.

## Decision-making tools

Simulating air quality scenarios to evaluate the impact of the actions, the best way to plan-make.

## Where

Maputo / Asunción / Port Vila / Dakar / Yakutsk

## Context

Lobelia leads a commercially-oriented air quality consortium, born from a European H2020 project, with some of the most renowned European actors in air pollution research.

Air pollution is a serious problem that costs billions of euros each year in lost productivity and health expenses. In addition, air quality pollution also has a negative economic impact on other activities such as transport (e.g. lack of visibility), city maintenance (e.g. infrastructure cleaning) or agriculture (e.g. pollutant depositions) that cause 3 million deaths worldwide each year.

The AirQast project is building a self-sustainable platform providing air quality services based on Earth Observation data. 


```Button
label: check it online
url: http://airqast.com
```

## Emissions

## Forecast

## Decision-making tools

## Where

China / India / Europe

## Context

Lobelia leads a commercially-oriented air quality consortium, born from a European H2020 project, with some of the most renowned European actors in air pollution research.

Air pollution is a serious problem that costs billions of euros each year in lost productivity and health expenses. In addition, air quality pollution also has a negative economic impact on other activities such as transport (e.g. lack of visibility), city maintenance (e.g. infrastructure cleaning) or agriculture (e.g. pollutant depositions) that cause 3 million deaths worldwide each year.

cHJvamVjdC1jb250ZW50c19Mb2JlbGlhIGhhcyBk.text:
Lobelia has developed a system to predict trends of extreme climate events at specific locations. The system is fed with observations and climate models, as well as reanalysis and satellite datasets. Data sources include leading European meteorological agencies, ECMWF, Sentinel imagery and various local data providers.

We use **computational intelligence techniques** to find patterns in the climate models that correlate with the temporal density of extreme events in the past, according to real observations from meteorological agencies. These results are then projected into the future according to the existing climate models.

Our studies have found that the evolution in time of the probabilities of occurrence differ substantially depending on the event (e.g. extraordinary winds, cyclones and extreme storms) and the location. Specific studies are required in every context to obtain optimum results for each extreme event category.

```Button
label: try demo
url: https://region-climate-trends.lobelia.earth/{lang}
langs:
- en
- es
- ca
- fr
- zh
```

cHJvamVjdC1jb250ZW50c18jIyBFbWlzc2lvbnMK.text:
## Emissions

Monthly regional emission inventories from satellites at 1-km resolution.

## Forecast

Hourly air quality forecasts for 3 days in advance.

## Decision-making tools

Simulating air quality scenarios to evaluate the impact of the actions, the best way to plan-make.

## Where

China / India / Europe

## Context

Lobelia leads a commercially-oriented air quality consortium, born from a European H2020 project, with some of the most renowned European actors in air pollution research.

Air pollution is a serious problem that costs billions of euros each year in lost productivity and health expenses. In addition, air pollution also has a negative economic impact on other activities such as transport (e.g. lack of visibility), city maintenance (e.g. infrastructure cleaning) or agriculture (e.g. pollutant depositions) that cause 3 million deaths worldwide each year.

The AirQast project is building a self-sustainable platform providing air quality services based on Earth Observation data. 


```Button
label: learn more
url: http://airqast.com
newTab: true
```

cHJvamVjdC1jb250ZW50c19PbmUgb2YgdGhlIG1v.text:
One of the most frequently heard phrases in Earth Observation is “bringing the algorithms to the data”. Given the increasingly large datasets provided by Sentinel satellites and Copernicus services, platforms are emerging that do just that: helping users run their processing chains as close as possible to the data they need — no need to wait for huge downloads before even starting.

**Lobelia works with Mercator Océan International** aiding Earth Observation users to get the most out of [WEkEO](https://wekeo.eu), the Data and Information Access Services (DIAS) platform developed by EUMETSAT, ECMWF and Mercator itself. Lobelia is also deeply involved in monitoring the various services, as well as gathering feedback for the next releases of the platform.

```Button
label: learn more
url: https://wekeo.eu
newTab: true
```

cHJvamVjdC10aXRsZV9IZWxwaW5nIGNpdGllcyB0.text: Helping cities to *turn green* with air quality knowledge from satellites

cGFnZS1jb250ZW50c19XZSB1c2UgRWFydGggT2Jz.text: We use Earth Observation data and climate projections for the assessment of **vulnerabilities, risks and opportunities associated to climate scenarios** for each particular case and region of interest. We work on monitoring, forecasting and planning, often from open and free data acquired by European satellites under the Copernicus programme.

cHJvamVjdC1jb250ZW50c19DbGltYXRlIGNoYW5n.text:
Climate change is expected to disproportionately affect smallholder farmers, who already face numerous risks to their agricultural production. Crop varieties will respond differently to changes in temperature and precipitation at the locations where they are currently grown. A **crop suitability index** is an important component of assessment studies, including changes to geographical crop distribution under climate change in the coming decades.

** In collaboration with Oxfam, Lobelia has developed a crop suitability tool to assess the future of staple crops in different regions.**

## Sahel

Maize / sorghum / pearl millet

## Sub-Saharan Africa

Maize / sorghum / pearl millet / rice / cassava / beans / groundnuts / yam

## Dry Corridor

Maize / sorghum / beans / rice


```Button
label: try demo

langs:
- en
- es
- ca
- fr
```

cHJvamVjdC1jb250ZW50c19Mb2JlbGlhIGhhcyBk.text:
Lobelia has developed a system to predict trends of extreme climate events at specific locations. The system is fed with observations and climate models, as well as reanalysis and satellite datasets. Data sources include leading European meteorological agencies, ECMWF, Sentinel imagery and various local data providers.

We use **computational intelligence techniques** to find patterns in the climate models that correlate with the temporal density of extreme events in the past, according to real observations from meteorological agencies. These results are then projected into the future according to the existing climate models.

Our studies have found that the evolution in time of the probabilities of occurrence differ substantially depending on the event (e.g. extraordinary winds, cyclones and extreme storms) and the location. Specific studies are required in every context to obtain optimum results for each extreme event category.

**Lobelia collaborates with PwC on the economic assessment of potential damages derived from extreme climate events.** 

```Button
label: request a demo
url: mailto:info@lobelia.earth
```

cHJvamVjdC1jb250ZW50c19VcmJhbiBhcmVhcyBh.text:
Urban areas are strongly exposed to the effects of climate change. Local authorities monitor these effects very closely, so that they can adapt in a timely manner and reduce their impact on citizens' lives: health care, transport, water management, energy supply, etc.

UN Habitat's **City Resilience Profiling Programme (CRPP)** provides national and local governments with tools for measuring and increasing resilience to multi-hazard impacts, including those associated with climate change.

**Lobelia's climate engine is integrated in the CRPP**, helping analyse climate trends and link to other types of data as required to allow the definition of a suitable action plan. Lobelia's toolbox can be used by cities worldwide, with current users including Asunción, Yakutsk, Maputo, Dakar and Port Vila.

Lobelia uses downscaling and bias correction techniques to generate high-resolution, locally-adapted data describing the future climate in the target cities. 


```Button
label: try demo
url: https://city-climate-trends.lobelia.earth/{lang}
langs:
- en
- es
- ca
- fr
- zh
- ru
```

cHJvamVjdC1jb250ZW50c19GbG9vZHMgYXJlIGEg.text:
Floods are a rapidly growing concern in West Africa, projected to increase with climate change. There is a great need for reliable access to operational flood forecasts and alerts, produced by a robust information and communication system, adapted to regional conditions and operated by capable West African institutions.

The EC-funded FANFAR project aims at building such a system. In this context, Lobelia's **satellite-based water level products** of the Niger River basin floodplain are sequentially assimilated into a hydrological model from the Swedish Meteorological and Hydrological Institute (SMHI) to generate river discharge return periods. These results are then used in SMHI’s flood forecasting and early-warning alert system in West Africa.

**The cloud-based [Hydrology Thematic Exploitation Platform (H-TEP)](https://hydrology-tep.eo.esa.int) operates this flood warning system.** Lobelia's satellite-based, global water level service runs on the H-TEP and is well-suited to complement in-situ sensor networks. It can also be used as a proxy of streamflow, for model calibration and validation as well as for hydrologic data assimilation.

```Button
label: learn more
url: http://fanfar.eu
newTab: true
```

cHJvamVjdC1jb250ZW50c19BIHN3YXJtIG1lYXN1.text:
A swarm measuring one square kilometre contains about 40 million locusts, which eat the same amount of food in one day as approximately 35,000 people.

More than 8 million people in West Africa were affected during the 2003-2005 plague, in which cereal crops were wiped out and up to 90% of legumes and pasture were destroyed. It took nearly $600 million and 13 million litres of pesticide to bring it under control.

Satellite data is being used in a novel way to predict favourable conditions for desert locust swarms. The new technology, largely based on **high-resolution soil moisture** data, helps to increase the warning time for locust outbreaks by up to two months.

A new tool was developed by isardSAT and Cirad, under a contract with the European Space Agency, to monitor and forecast the conditions that can lead to locust swarms, such as high moisture and green vegetation. Swarming occurs when a period of drought is followed by abundant rains and rapid vegetation growth. Results were validated in Algeria, Mali, Mauritania and Morocco in coordination with National Authorities and FAO.

During the latest outbreak in Mauritania (2016), the team was able to identify a time lag of about 70 days from the initial signs of soil moisture to when the outbreak eventually occurred. These results were obtained using Earth observation data from the **operational soil moisture service with global coverage operated today by Lobelia**.


```Button
label: learn more
url: http://smells.isardsat.com/
newTab: true
```

cHJvamVjdC1jb250ZW50c18qKkxvYmVsaWEqKiBp.text:
**Lobelia** is created to respond to the societal needs for regulatory measures to confront climate change. The Kyoto protocol and COP21 are just two of the major forums where decisions have been made internationally to work collaboratively and address climate-based challenges and set up a path for a new economy. This new economy takes into account collective responsibility with respect to the impact of climate change upon private sector operations and public policy.  One example is the European Directive for the disclosure of non-financial information for large groups and the commitment of major investment firms to environmentally sustainable outcomes.

With more than ten years of experience, **isardSAT** is a leading expert on satellite technologies, satellite mission design and implementation as well as on proprietary algorithms for the application of satellite technology for environmental issues, and is now proud to present its new business unit: *Lobelia*.

Lobelia has been created with the clear objective of putting satellite data, computational intelligence and climate information to use for the creation of strategic plans and adaption measures in the face of climate change.

Today, the team at Lobelia is composed of passionate experts in physics, earth science, graphic design, data visualisation and computational intelligence. We work with trusted data providers and have a growing network of international collaborators that are as engaged as we are to drive for change.

cHJvamVjdC1jb250ZW50c19BaXJRYXN0IG9mZmVy.text:
AirQast offers a portfolio of air quality products derived from satellite data. Originating from a European H2020 project, AirQast includes some of the most renowned European actors in air pollution research.

**Lobelia operates the AirQast platform and provides air quality services at urban scales.**

## Emissions

Monthly regional emission inventories from satellites at 1-km resolution.

## Forecast

Hourly air quality forecasts for 3 days in advance.

## Decision-making tools

Scenario simulations to evaluate the impact of air quality measures in cities/regions and plan accordingly.

## Where

China / India / Europe / other regions upon demand.

## Context

Air pollution is a serious problem traced to 3 million deaths worldwide every year. It also causes yearly costs in the order of billions of euros, considering lost productivity and health expenses. Finally, pollution impacts negatively on aspects such as transport (e.g. lack of visibility in airports), city maintenance (e.g. infrastructure cleaning) and agriculture (e.g. pollutant depositions).


```Button
label: learn more
url: http://airqast.com
newTab: true
```

Given the increasingly large datasets provided by Sentinel satellites and Copernicus services, platforms are emerging that do just that: helping users run their processing chains as close as possible to the data they need — no need to wait for huge downloads before even starting.

**Lobelia collaborates with Mercator Océan International aiding Earth Observation users to get the most out of [WEkEO](https://wekeo.eu)**, the Data and Information Access Services (DIAS) platform developed by EUMETSAT, ECMWF and Mercator itself. Lobelia is also deeply involved in monitoring the various services, as well as gathering feedback for the next releases of the platform.


Lobelia's toolbox can be used by cities worldwide, with current users including Asunción, Yakutsk, Maputo, Dakar and Port Vila.

Lobelia uses downscaling and bias correction techniques to generate high-resolution, locally-adapted data describing the future climate in the target cities.
